comments:

We're using the WSWD version (wswb-SDK-wswb-RC1-win32.zip).

I have been able to reproduce it.  Interestingly only Infocenter is affected, 
standalone help works fine.

Yes, I noticed that standalone seemed to work.  Sorry, I forgot to
include that in the bug.

BTW . . . with rc51, standalone seems to come up in a browser.
Why the change?

Bob, the stack dump was caused by not synchronizing building of the toc's.The 
toolbar buttons were not working because there was a missing javascript file (I 
think this is a regression). 
The fix will make it into the next build, so please let us know how it works 
for you.

As for launching the browser in the standalone: is you standalone package using 
the minimal set of plugins? If that's the case, then this is the expected 
behavior. If you are running standalone with the full eclipse install, then 
there is a bug.
Released fixes for the stack trace and synchronization.

Re: As for launching the browser in the standalone: is you standalone package using 
the minimal set of plugins? If that's the case, then this is the expected 
behavior. 

O.K. . . . so which plugins do I need, in addition to the
minimum set. I've been trying various plugins and various 
combinations, but haven't hit on what's needed yet.

This is from the online docs, look at the last set of plugins:

The stand-alone help does not require the entire  Eclipse Platform package. It 
is possible to run the stand-alone help with the following plug-ins (located in 
the  eclipse\plugins directory):


org.apache.lucene
org.apache.xerces
org.eclipse.core.boot
org.eclipse.core.resources
org.eclipse.core.runtime
org.eclipse.help
org.eclipse.help.appserver
org.eclipse.help.webapp
org.eclipse.tomcat
org.eclipse.update.core


In addition to these plugins, depending on the operating system or machine 
architecture, you may need to also need to install the corresponding fragments 
for the above plugins (when they exist). For example, on Windows, you need to 
add the following fragments (also located in the eclipse\plugins directory):


org.eclipse.core.resources.win32
org.eclipse.update.core.win32


On Windows, it is possible to provide a different help browser (an SWT-embedded 
Internet Explorer web browser) by adding the following plugins and fragments on 
top of the minimal configuration: 

org.eclipse.help.ui.win32
org.eclipse.help.ui
org.eclipse.jface.text
org.eclipse.jface
org.eclipse.search
org.eclipse.swt.win32
org.eclipse.swt
org.eclipse.text
org.eclipse.ui.editors
org.eclipse.ui.views
org.eclipse.ui.win32_2.1.0 
org.eclipse.ui.workbench.texteditor
org.eclipse.ui.workbench
org.eclipse.ui
